title: League of Legends
body:
I LOVE this game. I started playing in July of last year, stopped for a little while. Now I really got into it and at the moment I play this game everyday. I explore different champs on my smurf account. I wanna be world ranked someday (not likely though. Not very good yet). The one thing I can't stand has little to do with the game itself. 

It's the people. 

Not everyone. But it seems like every lobby I get into SOMEBODY is doing something to instigate or make people feel like shit. Why? Why does that have to happen. I understand that there is a mute button. But there shouldn't **_have_** to be a mute button. People should be respectful of others. If you don't want to help the new person, then don't be mean to them either. It's honestly worse than playing with 12 year olds on Call of Duty. If it wasn't for how much fun I have with this game then I might not play anymore, solely on the fact that people are so toxic for no apparent reason. 

You are not going to win every game. So when you have someone that is doing bad, don't harass them. It's just not right.

replies.body: ha ha ha ha. Your view of humanity. Good luck. Treat them as they are not how you wish them to be. People are shits cause this is the internet.
You can't do that though because if you treat them as they are, you get punished.

You also become part of the problem when you do that.

When you start thinking everybody's a jerk and treating them as such, you become the jerk who needs to get muted.


Treat people how you wish to be treated. It won't always mean you get treated that way back, but at least you will be treated that way back sometimes rather than never.
Assuming that all people "are shits" is going to create a cycle. You treat everybody like shit because you think they are, they treat you like shit because _you are being a shit_ in this scenario.

It only takes one player to ruin a game for 4-9 people. If that player only ruined it because they entered the game already convinced they're playing with a team of jerks that's just really sad. It could have easily been avoided simply by giving people a reasonable chance first.

Well what about those people that come about and are assholes for no apparent reason other than just to be an asshole? And they can do multiple things to ruin that game for you regardless of whether they are muted or not. Because they can still troll you with pings, certain champs abilities can effect the team negatively if used the wrong way, they could intentionally feed/go afk/throw the game, etc. And you can't say anything negative back or leave without being punished as well. How is that fair to the decent people that play league? The volume of trolls is incredible. I find that I have one in 4/5 games that I play. All the decent players are continuous victims to them because there is nothing that can be done about it. 

Yeah, you say to treat people how you want to be treated, and that can be good for preventing harassment (which it is) in the first place. But what happens after they already start? What are you supposed to do? Turn the other cheek and let the other side of your face be verbally beat inside out? I don't think that's right.

You ignore it and move on at the very least. You can kindly suggest they relax or you can also react to it in a way they don't expect by being respectful and not feeding into it much like parents do to their children. Reacting to it by returning the negativity does not solve anything. The mute button exists so you don't have to turn the other cheek. I _highly_ doubt you're experiencing games more often than not where people are being so toxic they purposely feed, ping the map, and do all other sorts of trolling they can do after being muted. When they are, report them. You might have just helped save another player from having to experience that, the same way that that other player's reports might have saved you from another game with a player like that.

Chances are the guy being an asshole had a shitty game just before he got into yours and let himself become a negative player from it. He's part of a chain reaction. It probably didn't start with him, but it could have stopped with him.

A negative player can ripple negativity out into future games they're not even in through other players. A positive player (and even a neutral player) can ripple out as well. You'll experience positive games that are a direct result of somebody in another game not letting toxicity get to them and not carrying that burden into their next game infecting more people.


Try to remain positive, at the very least just be neutral. The dangers of a toxic player are their ability to spread the toxicity. When you let them get to you, you become another toxic player that people, just like you, are coming to the forums and complaining about. Becoming the problem is not a solution to the problem.

I'm not trying to become part of the problem or enhance the problem in any way. I'm saying, why not be given the choice on how to handle any particular verbal situation? Why should we be restricted to how we handle a verbal situation. I recently learned that there was a mute button, which I will be using more often. But I still think that certain things said deserve to be given a response.

Maybe its just how I was raised, but I don't let people walk all over me. And its tough for me personally to resist reacting to someone that insults me or takes steps to get me going.

I can see that my way of thinking isn't going to get very far right now lol. So maybe I should conform, but I still think we should be able to handle the situation in a way that we see fit. I mean, we play this game, we should have a say, right? I'm pretty confident that I'm not the only one that feels this way.

It helps if you dont view them as "walking over you" by raging at you with no response.
If someone is flaming, and you dont respond, you've won, they dont get the satisfaction of your emotional response. 
If someone is REALLY looking for a fight, the best way to beat them is to not let them find one.

I would agree with you... If there was only two people on a team.

But your words reach not only the rager... but the other three people on your team. Why would you want to make this game worse for them? And yes, it will be worse if you retaliate in kind. Instead of one nasty person, it's two. Instead of somebody talking to the air they'll be talking to a person - which will feed their ragey behavior. Instead of one person stopping to type periodically (and thus not play as well) it's two.

Why would you want to make the game worse for those three innocent players on your team?

> But I still think that certain things said deserve to be given a response.

Nope, nope and nope.

You don't add fuel to a blazing fire.

The stronger person of two is the one who **doesn't** react.

We are on the internet, behind a screen; how could someone "walk over you"? it' s only pitiful for him that it' s shouting to a screen, so don' t worry about that and if you really think that way, then let me tell that YOU can be the one who walks over his taunts ;)

... it' s a bit douchei this way, but who i am to judge?

guy is right but easier said than done

Sometimes... people need a reminder they're being a dick in a civil manner. I've told people that their comments are uncalled for or a little extreme and they've apologized for it and act fine and dandy the rest of the game. It doesn't always happen, but it's worth a shot.
I've had games where this happens with another person immediately retaliating. The first person has apologized, but the third is just so far gone by the guy's initial comment that this "victim" becomes the problem. The first then goes back to the initial mindset and the apology goes out the window because now he's being attacked. If person C had been quiet, it's entirely possible the game could have continued in harmony.
Then I've had games where one smart ass remark set another person off to troll the game to "teach him a lesson about being a dick to his team". Again, the "victim" became the bigger problem.
In general... When somebody responds to a rager with more nastiness... the whole problem gets a whole lot worse. I can ignore one ass with relative ease. Two people at each others throat just makes me want to afk.

Remember, there are three other people on your team other than just you and the aggressor. And I personally would rather one nasty dick over two.

Also keep in mind, there is a set of trolls that enjoys getting a reaction out of people. Don't feed the trolls.

In short, yes. That's exactly what you're supposed to do. You ignore them. That's how you deal with jerks and assholes in real life, it should be not different in game. Trolls LIVE for people like you, they LOVE it when people start fighting back. You're only encouraging them to continue that behavior. 

Nobody's saying you have to be nice to trolls and jerks, just that you shouldn't be fighting them. Save politeness for the good people, the people who deserve it. But for people who are complete assholes? Mute them, and focus on trying to get as much out of the match as you can.  Fighting with people online NEVER gets anyone anywhere, and makes it more difficult to play the game. You end up losing whatever little hope you have of turning the match around because you effectively turn a 4v5 into a 3v5.
"Whoever fights monsters should see to it that in the process he does not become a monster. And if you gaze long enough into the abyss, the abyss will gaze back into you."
Whoa breaking out the Nietzche

the problem is, I've been playing this game for almost 5 years now. It gets really hard to do that when you've taken so much abuse over the course of that time.

I still remember when I used to truely care about being positive to other players, but I've just become so worn down, I just don't care anymore. I don't go out of my way to be rude every game, but I'm definitely not nearly as positive as I used to be, and I try not to interact with my team as much anymore because I've come to expect the hate and rage that they will most assumedly produce. :(

I still have my good moments tho, where I'm positive, but if I'm not negative, I'm definitely a lot more neutral than I used to be.

Either that or they're intellectually challenged, but that's nothing they can do anything about.

I usually solo queue, although I sometimes get invited to games.

I'm implying something, but the general trend is that anyone who complains about the community is themselves toxic.

Lyte did some research into it awhile back and everyone who commented saying the community was shit were the only people actually being toxic.

Surprisingly actually toxic people are a very rare occurrence.
Do you have a link to this? I don't doubt you but I am interested.

It was on the forums and I'm far too lazy to cite sources, you're welcome to discredit me if you want if you find the sources. It was also mentioned in a reddit comment section, which I'm not going to try to find either, and it appears its the same thing on reddit as well.

One of the mods responded to a comment lyte said about this topic and the mod reaffirmed that it was also true on reddit. The people constantly complaining about the community being toxic are the people the mods have to warn often as they're generally toxic.

I also have my own hypothesis for this as to why this is true. Simply put, the chances of you getting someone really toxic in your games if you say nothing at all is rather low, like 1/10 games. The people who complain about the community either create a toxic chat themselves, or they get 'triggered' by a rather insignificant comment.

For example:

---

*Rager Died to Jungle*

p1: Rager....

Rager: stfu I'm reporting you, you toxic piece of shit.

----

Now who's the truly toxic one in that scenario? p1 certainly wasn't in the right but that is never something he'd get reprimanded for, Rager on the other hand was incredibly toxic. They aren't all as simple as this, but this is generally what happens. I believe this what you call them having a chip on their shoulder, they just think there's a much bigger problem than there is. This in turn creates a toxic and negative atmosphere.

Also something else, if you're just playing the game and having your own good time, chance are you don't really notice the chat. There are games where there are just an apparent amount of toxicity in the chat that I don't see going on for like 5 minutes, and I only ever notice it now and then. Non-toxic people generally just ignore the toxicity and don't think much of it, where as toxic people are much more likely to notice it.

I'm not saying this is true to everyone and in every occurrence, but as someone who's been positive, toxic, and neutral themselves to a very high extent this is what I've found. Yes I've been all of those and you'd be surprised what your mentality affects. If you're being toxic chances are you're in a bad mood and you're doing worse, which just snowballs toxicity and makes you notice your own actions less driving it onto other team mates and vice versa.

I choose to be nice every game. I don't mute, even the most toxic of players. I still need to see communications from the team, there might be a pivotal play that happens because of something they say (I've had a few games where a player got muted by several people, but I had to relay important information they were noticing). I can't change the world or the way people play, but I can control how I play.

Hence LOL is free because YOU are the product they are serving to paying players.  All the rest, the tribunal, moderation, dev posts, etc... its all smoke and mirrors.  They rarely if ever ban (if you don't believe try to actually get a ban, you have to be so egregiously toxic is ridiculous to even get a day or 2 ban), the 'reporting' system is intentionally ineffective and ambiguous, and the game design at its very core is selfish.

I realize the severity of the troll situation and the immaturity of the people who play this game. There is no short-term fix no matter what you may want to try. TRY TEAMBUILDER! I have yet to find someone (intentionally) trolling my game, mostly because teams are reviewed by the owner before going into a game. You also have the option of leaving a lobby to find a new team if someone looks as if they might troll. Once you get the "new champion adjustments" inactive, then you really begin to play with strong players who can actually work as a good team(btw the way to make the adjustments inactive is to play a certain champion many times, and it makes the game believe you are now skilled at that champion). I used to play Blind Queue and I absolutely hated it, someone usually dodged, and I almost never got my ideal lane and champion. I always had someone doing really badly or just completely exaggerating every mistake they made, as if it was fatal to them. 

Play Teambuilder, the ONLY downsides are the wait times, which are irrelevant if you pick ADC, Jungle, or Support. You find the team you want, at the skill level(hopefully) you want, and you play against a competent enemy who will (hopefully) be sportsmanlike. :)

People are A-Holes...if you were to actually be forced to interact with as many people in person as you do online...you would notice the same trend. Mankind has many problems...and rarely is able to get along with itself. Its why war is even a thing.
